p: The traditional empirical approach of testing a causal link between a factor and an outcome of an experiment was to vary one factor at a time, while keeping the other factors (experimental conditions) constant. This ‘all the rest of the conditions are equal’ assumption is often referred to by its Latin form as ceteris paribus. R.A. Fisher ([ Fisher, 1935], p. 18) noted that, in real-life experiments, perfect ceteris paribus is not achievable ‘because uncontrollable causes which may influence the results are always … innumerable.’ Fisher’s proposed solution to this problem is to design experiments to involve random assignment of treatment (the putative causal factorâ€™s states) to individual trials and then use regression analysis to estimate the value and significance of the putative causal effect.
